ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Excellent guest speakers!
Frances B was the instructor of this course, not Mr. Crane. Frances is the Bomb. She's the best. And this class was awesome.

The reason I mentioned that this course is a particularly valuable is because as a scientist I don't think that there was a lot of focus on how people who are in the scientific field can help in the fight against climate change. Heidi Cullen was really the only representative, in the course had a pretty distinct policy bent.
This course is obviously unique, but I am very glad that it was offered. It helped me to think about the type of environmental career I hoped to pursue. I was very pleased with the course.

Frances was our instructor not Peter--it was obviously a very non-traditional course but a fantastic array of speakers and conversations for those interested in environmental justice and environmental communications.

Firstly, Peter Crane should NOT be listed as the instructor but instead it should be Frances Beinecke. This is an unfortunate error because the dean was only there a handful of times and the course was clearly run by Frances. There is no way to evaluate Frances' excellent leadership in this course because of this administrative oversight and so I'd like to state here that she commanded each week's lecture very well, able to respond to students' comments and questions and linking it back to the speaker very gracefully.

Peter Crane was generally absent from the course sessions. Frances Beinecke introduced all speakers and hosted the discussion afterward. The questions would have been more relevant had they asked about Frances.
I declined to answer Q's 8-10 because Dean Crane wasn't really present in this class. Frances Beinecke was great and I would give her... Q8 - 2 Q9 - 3 Q10 - 2

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The diversity of the speakers. Consistently interesting and organized.
I really enjoyed our discussions about the importance of diversity / the current lack of representation in climate change discussion. Many of the speakers were both inspiring and informative.
The diversity in the backgrounds of the speakers and areas of focus on addressing climate change.
Loved Rev Yearwood, Cullen, Mair
The best aspects of this course were the extremely knowledgeable people who were brought in to speak and the interactions between speak and the audience.

The food. Also offering up such an awesome panel of speakers on climate change. This class was a lot of fun. And I don't mean that in a pejorative way. Policy is made by schmoozing. And this class offered us the opportunity to get together, over food and drinks, with friends, members of the community, and distinguished speakers, and share ideas. It was a blast.

The opportunity to hear from and interact with individuals working in different spheres of climate action was invaluable. Being connected to what is happening off campus makes on-campus learning all the more important.

Simply the diversity of different people that came to speak at FES this fall. They all give very enlightening talks all very different but very thought-provoking. I wish we would've had more time to discuss the speakers with Francis throughout the semester, I was really disappointed that only four people showed up to the one discussion section that was scheduled. I also would've really like to talk about the personalities and skills of the individuals that came to speak and how those skills in experiences that they had ultimately led them to the career that they have. I think more of the focus was on whether each organization had positions and skills that they were looking for. But I found that I would've liked to know a little bit more about the speakers that didn't share so much about their background.

The diverse array of speakers with different theories of change was this course's greatest asset. It allowed me to leave this course with a newfound understanding of the complexities of making environmental change and the myriad ways of seeking that change. Frances Beinecke's participation in the course was also a huge asset. She brought a helpful and realistic perspective to all aspects of the course.
We heard from so many fascinating people about so many fascinating things!
It was great to be exposed to so many different environmental leaders.
Really fantastic set of speakers brought in!

A true diverse selection of speakers were presented. From ethnic to professional diversity, it was very well put together and every week had a different angle of the story. There were those with more power than others or more experience than others, but it was a welcomed breath of fresh air from the traditional FES courses in that it was grounded very much in reality and it painted the way the world will look when all of us graduate from FES. It provided a sense of real world issues, even oftentimes in arenas outside of the environmental sciences.

The ability to hear from a multitude of speakers currently in the environmental arena was great. The one-on-one dinners after some of the sessions provided great opportunities to talk to the speakers and become more familiar with their work.
Great networking opportunities for students interested in the field.
This class was great--best aspects were bringing in people of color working in the environmental field and hearing what they're doing, their stories, and what they think needs to change.
The amazing group of speakers that Frances put together and getting to have dinner with a few of them.

This course was a fantastic introduction to issues of diversity and climate justice within the environmental sphere. I felt this course exposed many to the intersections of race, class and environmentalism for the first time. It was amazing to have the opportunity to talk to such important people within the movement and I learned so much!

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: There were several speakers whose discussion was conducted in too many generalities / weren't that illuminating.
Get someone better from clean tech!
It probably could have benefited from a mandatory discussion section.

I really don't think the course needs to be improved, however I do think one or two more discussion sessions would've been really valuable in tying every thing together. Especially when thinking about how to summarize one's ideas in the position paper, discussions like this would've been helpful.
I thought that the expectations for the assignments could have been more clear.
There was no support; I literally never interacted with our professor or TA--had no idea what was expected for projects.
Perhaps adding a government official would have been good.
Perhaps some sort of monthly discussion section or weekly assignment would be helpful to keep students engaged.
It lacked diversity, and diverse voices was the title of the course.
It is a pass/fail class that is mainly a lecture series. I think it was great and the speakers were all very different and very interesting!

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There was one discussion section and it was poorly attended.
Would have loved one more opportunity to go to a section - the one held was during another class I was taking!
There was only one optional discussion section throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It was a great half course to supplement an undergraduate environmental studies course I am taking called Climate Change Communications for Public Policy.
Climate change and its impacts are of grave concern for public health. All MPH students should be required to take this course!

This course I think is valuable not so much for my program but just for general understanding of the climate change realm. I think many students are focusing on this topic in their studies in FES but I'm not one of those people.

As an undergraduate hoping to pursue a career in the energy field, I found this course helpful in thinking about the costs and benefits to working on issues of sustainable energy in different sectors (government, NGO, business).

I am interested in environmental policy and before FES I had a very different set of experiences that led me to look at the grassroots environmental movement differently. By the end of this course, I have a newfound respect for what all the different leaders of the movement are doing and furthermore, I have incorporated their ideas and successes directly in my other classes. I think the views presented were very well done because each person came from a different path that led them to their current position and each one had a story that people could relate to in a different way. During some weeks perhaps I identified with some more than other speakers, but I always respected what they had to say and it was evident they were passionate about their occupations. It was both educational and inspiring to hear and learn from them and it provided a strong, complementary discourse to my other foundations classes.

I am interested in policy and governance, so hearing about some people currently involved in this arena was helpful. It was also useful hearing about the different things people are doing to combat climate change.
This class was a nice supplement to my courses and a great was to hear from professionals in the field.
I'm an environmental studies major so fits very well! I am also an undergrad so it was great to get this experience at the forestry school.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Was looking for an elective in an area I haven't explored yet.
I would have come seen this amazing speakers in any case! Having it more officially structured into my time was helpful.
I took this course in order to be exposed to different ideas and perspectives surrounding climate change.
I took this course because the lectures sounded interesting, Frances Beinecke has always been an inspiring figure and I hoped to gain insight into the various ways to seek environmental change.
Once in a lifetime class because Frances is only temporarily here! And I think I am majoring in Environmental Studies, from a non-sciencey vantage point.
Great set of speakers and a unique format!

Frances is a huge leader in the environmental movement and I knew I had to take advantage of this somewhat once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. Also I thought it was interesting to bring it all the different speakers from all parts of the environmental world.
I wanted to hear the different perspectives in the environmental field to understand what is being done to address climate change.
The speakers seemed interesting and diversity is an important issue.
Was excited to hear from leaders in climate justice -- most environmental courses ignore the social justice aspect of the environment and this one finally didn't!

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Exceeded my expectations.
Yes. My perspectives were widened and deepened from the speakers who came.
Yes I'd say so
I was satisfied with the new insights and perspectives I gained as a result of taking this course.
Yes! I feel very broadened.
Yes, I was pleased with the exposure to a diversity of voices that students received.
Yes-they exceeded them.
Yes.
I'd say yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: NA

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Perhaps be more prepared to ask questions of the speakers. I think when I had more background about what each one of them was doing and what the organization was doing, I had time to do some research and I could ask relevant questions, but I wasn't able to do that as frequently as I'd like to have done.
This is a great extra course to take. Just make sure to bring an open-mind.
Light workload and interesting
Consider reading more about the speakers prior to their presentations so that you can take advantage of the question and answer portion.
Hearing these people speak is amazing, but then getting to go to dinner with them and getting to know Frances is great as well.
Take it ! It has fairly little work and is very interesting! Was great to see how broad the range of careers was within environmentalism.
